question: Question 1 Given a system of equations x + 2y + 2z = [latex]b_1[/latex] 5x + y + 3z = [latex]b_2[/latex] What of the following is true regarding its solutions

options.A: The system has a unique solution for any given [latex]b_1 \; and \; b_2[/latex]
options.B: The system will have infinitely many solutions for any given [latex]b_1 \; and \; b_2[/latex]
options.C: Whether or not a solution exists depends on the given [latex]b_1 \; and \; b_2[/latex]
options.D: The systems would have no solution for any values of [latex]b_1 \; and \; b_2[/latex]

question: Question 2 Let [latex]f(x)=xe^{-x}[/latex]. The maximum value of the function in the interval [latex](0,\infty )[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=xe^{-x}\\ f'(x)&=e^{-x}-xe^{-x}=0\\ e^{-x}(1-x)&=0\\ x&=1\\ f''(x)&=-e^{-x}-e^{-x}+xe^{-x}\\ &=e^{-x}(x-2)\\ f''(1)&=e^{-1}(-1)=-e^{-1} \lt 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence f(x) has maximum value at x=1 [latex]f(1)=1\cdot e^{-1}=e^{-1}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The solution for the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}=-9x[/latex] with initial conditions x(0)=1 and [latex]\frac{dx}{dt}|_{t=0}=1[/latex], is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}&=-9x\\ \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}+9x&=0\\ (D^2+9)x &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Auxiliary equation is [latex]m^2+9=0 [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} m&= \pm 3i\\ x&= C_1 \cos 3t+C_2 \sin 3t\;\;...(i)\\ x(0) &=1\;\;i.e.\;x\rightarrow 1\; when t\rightarrow 0 \\ 1&=C_1 \\ \frac{dx}{dt}&=-3C_1 \sin 3t+3C_2 \cos 3t\;\;...(ii) \\ x'(0)&=1\;\; i.e.\;x'\rightarrow 1\; when \; t\rightarrow 0 \\ 1&=3C_2 \\ C_2&=\frac{1}{3}\\ \therefore \;x&=\cos 3t+\frac{1}{3}\sin 3t \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Let [latex]X(s)=\frac{3s+5}{s^{2}+10s+21}[/latex] be the Laplace Transform of a signal x(t). Then, x([latex]0^+[/latex]) is
solution: Given,  [latex]X(s)=\left [ \frac{3s+5}{s^2+10s+21} \right ][/latex] Using initial value theorem, [latex]\begin{aligned} x(0^+) &= \lim_{s \to \infty }[sX(s)]\\ x(0^+) &= \lim_{s \to \infty } \left [ \frac{s(3s+5)}{s^2+10+21} \right ] \\ &= \lim_{s \to \infty }\left [ \frac{3+\frac{5}{s}}{1+\frac{10}{s}+\frac{21}{s^2}} \right ]=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Let S be the set of points in the complex plane corresponding to the unit circle. (That is, S={z:|z|=1}). Consider the function f(z)=zz* where z* denotes the complex conjugate of z. The f(z) maps S to which one of the following in the complex plane
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} z&=x+iy\\ z^*&=x-iy\\ zz^*&=(x+iy)(x-iy)\\ &=x^2+y^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] which is equal to (1) always as given [latex]\begin{aligned} |z|&=1\\ zz^*&=x^2+y^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.B: horizontal axis line segment from origin to (1, 0)

question:
Question 6 The three circuit elements shown in the figure are part of an electric circuit. The
total power absorbed by the three circuit elements in watts is _____.
solution: Given electrical circuit is shown below: Applying KCL at node, current through 15V voltage source =2 A Power absorbed by 100 V voltage source = 10x100=1000 Watt. Power absorbed by 80 V voltage source =-(80x8)=-640 Watts and power absorbed by 15 V voltage source = -(15x2)=-30 Watt. Therefore,  total power absorbed by the three circuit element=(100-640-30_ watts =330 Watts

question: Question 7 [latex]C_0[/latex] is the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor with air as dielectric (as in figure (a)). If, half of the entire gap as shown in figure (b) is filled with a dielectric of permittivity [latex]\epsilon _r[/latex] , the expression for the modified capacitance is
solution: Let A be the area of the parallel plate capacitor and d be the distance between the plates. Let [latex]C_1[/latex] be the capacitance of half portion with air as dielectic medium and [latex]C_2[/latex] be capacitance with a dielectic of permitivity, [latex]\varepsilon _r[/latex]. Then, [latex]C_1=\frac{\varepsilon _0 \left ( \frac{A}{2} \right )}{d}[/latex] (As area become half) and [latex]C_2=\frac{\varepsilon _0 \varepsilon _r \left ( \frac{A}{2} \right )}{d}[/latex] (As area becomes half) Now, these two capacitance will be in parallel if a voltage is applied between the plates as same potential difference will be there between both the capacitance. Equivalent capacitance is [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{eqv} &= C_1+C_2\\ &=\frac{\varepsilon _0 A}{2d}+ \frac{\varepsilon _0 \varepsilon _r A}{2d}\\ &= \frac{\varepsilon _0 A}{2d}(1+ \varepsilon _r)=\frac{C_0}{2}(1+\varepsilon _r) \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, modified capacitance, [latex]C_{eqv}=\frac{C_0}{2}(1+\varepsilon _r)[/latex]

question: Question 8 A combination of 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor with an initial voltage [latex]v_c(0)=-2V[/latex] in series with a 100 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor is connected to a 20 mA ideal dc current source by operating both switches at t=0s as shown. Which of the following graphs shown in the options approximates the voltage [latex]v_s[/latex] across the current source over the next few seconds ?
solution: Given [latex]C=1\mu F, V_c(0)=-2V[/latex],  [latex]R=100\Omega , I=20mA[/latex]. Circuit fot the given condition at time [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] is shown below: Applying KVL, we have,[latex]V_s(s)=\left ( \frac{-2}{s} \right )+\frac{I}{s} \left ( R+\frac{I}{Cs} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s}\left [ -2+IR+\frac{I}{Cs} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s}\left [ (IR-2) +\frac{I}{Cs}\right ] [/latex] Putting values of R, C and I, we get, [latex]V_s(s)=\frac{1}{s}\left [ (20 \times 10^{-3} \times 200-2)+\left ( \frac{20 \times 10^{-3}}{10^{-6}} \right ) \times \frac{1}{s} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1}{s}\left [ (2-2)+20 \times 10^3 \times \frac{1}{s} \right ] [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{20 \times 10^3}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_s(s)=\frac{20 \times 10^3}{s^2} [/latex] [latex]V_s(t)=20000 t u(t) [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_s(s)=(20000)tu(t) [/latex] Which is equation of a straight line passing through origin. Hence option (C) is correct.

question: Question 9 x(t) is nonzero only for [latex]T_x \lt t \lt T'_x[/latex], and similarly, y(t) is nonzero only for [latex]T_y \lt t \lt T'_y[/latex]. Let z(t) be convolution of x(t) and y(t). Which one of the following statements is TRUE ?
solution: [latex]x(t)[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]T_x \lt t \lt T'_x[/latex] and [latex]y(t)[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]T_y \lt t \lt T'_y[/latex] [latex]\because \;\; z(t)=x(t)\otimes y(t)[/latex] then the limits of the resultant signal is [latex]T_x+T_y \lt t \lt T'_x+T'_y[/latex] i.e.  [latex]z(t)[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]T_x+T_y \lt t \lt T'_x+T'_y[/latex]

options.A: z(t) can be nonzero over an unbounded interval.
options.C: z(t) is zero outside of [latex]T_{x}+T_{y} \lt t \lt T'_{x}+T'_{y}[/latex]

question: Question 10 For a periodic square wave, which one of the following statements is TRUE ?
solution: Reconstruction of signal by its Fourier series coefficient is not possible at those points where signal is discontinuous. In the above figure, at integer multiples of 'T/2', signal recovery is not possible by using its coefficient. Therefore, reconstruction of x(t) by using its coefficient is possible at most of the points except those instants where x(t) is discontinous.

options.A: The Fourier series coefficients do not exist
options.B: The Fourier series coefficients exist but the reconstruction converges at no point
options.C: The Fourier series coefficients exist but the reconstruction converges at most point
options.D:
The Fourier series coefficients exist and the reconstruction converges at every
point.

question: Question 11 An 8-pole, 3-phase, 50 Hz induction motor is operating at a speed of 700 rpm. The frequency of the rotor current of the motor in Hz is ______.
solution: Given, [latex]P=8,f=50Hz, N_r=700\; \text{rpm} [/latex] Synchronous speed, [latex]N_s=\frac{120f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{8}=750 \text{rpm} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \;\;\text{Slip,}\;S&=\left ( \frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s} \right )\\ &= \left ( \frac{750-700}{750} \right )\\ &=\frac{50}{750}=\frac{1}{15} \end{aligned} [/latex] Therefore, frequency of rotor current, [latex]f_2=sf_1=\frac{1}{15} \times 50=3.33Hz [/latex] Hence, answer is 3.33Hz.

question: Question 12 For a specified input voltage and frequency, if the equivalent radius of the core of a transformer is reduced by half, the factor by which the number of turns in the primary should change to maintain the same no load current is
solution: Relucatance will be increased by two times. By considering flux density as constantflux should be reduced to 25% as area is reduced to 25% [latex]\begin{aligned} F&=\phi R\\ F' &= \frac{\phi }{4}\cdot 2R=\frac{R \phi }{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] For given current, number of turns should be reduced by half.

question:
Question 13 A star connected 400 V, 50 Hz, 4 pole synchronous machine gave the following
open circuit and short circuit test results : Open circuit test : [latex]V_{oc}[/latex] = 400 V (rms, line-to-line) at field current, [latex]I_{f}[/latex] = 2.3 A Short circuit test : [latex]I_{sc}[/latex]= 10 A (rms, phase) at field current,
[latex]I_{f}[/latex] = 1.5 A The value of per phase synchronous impedance in [latex]\Omega[/latex] at rated voltage is_____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given, for}\;\;V_{OC} &= 400V(rms)\\ &= \frac{400}{\sqrt{3}}\\ &= 230.94 \;\text{(Phase value),}\\ I_f&= 2.3A\\ \text{for}\;\; I_{sc}&=10A \;\text{(rms, phase)} \\ I_f&= 1.5A\\ & \therefore \;\;\text{Base impedance}\\ Z_{base}&=\frac{V_{OC}}{I_{sc}}\\ &=\frac{230.94}{10}=23.094\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] For finding the synchronous impedance at rated voltage, saturation effect of the machine has to be considered (i.e. the adjusted value of [latex]Z_s[/latex]) short circuit ratio, [latex]\begin{aligned} SCR &=\frac{I_f \;for \; V_{OC}}{I_f \;for \; I_{sc}} \\ &=\frac{1}{Z_{s_{(sat)pu}}} =\frac{2.3}{1.5}\\ Z_{s_{(sat)pu}} &= 0.65 pu \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, actual value of [latex]Z_s[/latex] at rated voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} &=Z_{s_{(sat)pu}} \times Z_{base} \\ &=0.65 \times 23.094=15.06\Omega \\ \therefore \;\;Z_s&= 15.06\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

and the current at bus A and [latex]V_{F2} \; and \; I_{F2}[/latex]  respectively. The correct statement
about voltages and currents during faults at  [latex]F_1 \; and \; F_2[/latex]  is

question: Question 16 A 2-bus system and corresponding zero sequence network are shown in the figure. The transformers T1 and T2 are connected as
solution: We have to use switch diagram for the zero-sequence network of transformer. Switch 1 or 2 is closed when winding in Yand neutral grounded. Switch 1 or 2 is closed when winding is in [latex]\Delta[/latex]. Given, for transformer [latex]T_1[/latex], switch 1 is closed and 2 is open. Therefore, transformer will be connected in primary with grounded neutral and secondary in star with isolated neutral. For transformer [latex]T_2[/latex], switch 1 is closed and 2 is closed, therefore, primary winding is star connected with neutral grounded whereas secondary will be delta connected.

question: Question 17 In the formation of Routh-Hurwitz array for a polynomial, all the elements of a row have zero values. This premature termination of the array indicates the presence of
solution: When all the element s of a row in Routh-Hurwitz array ends abruptly. i.e all elements of that row have a zero values then, the system will be either unstable or maginally stable. Marginally stable means it will have imaginary roots (two equal and opposite complex roots on imaginary axis of s-plane).

options.A: only one root at the origin

question: Question 18 The root locus of a unity feedback system is shown in the figure. The closed loop transfer function of the system is
solution: This is converse root locus having no zero. As, its [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] Its converse root locus only valid when [latex]K \lt 0[/latex] So, C.L.T.F.[latex]=\frac{G(s)H(s)}{1-G(s)H(s)} =\frac{\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)}}{1-\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)}} =\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)-K}[/latex]

question: Question 19 Power consumed by a balanced 3-phase, 3-wire load is measured by the two wattmeter method. The first wattmeter reads twice that of the second. Then, the load impedance angle in radians is
solution: For two wattmeter method, wattmeter readings are [latex]\begin{aligned} W_1 &=V_LI_L \cos (30+\phi ) \\ W_2 &=V_LI_L \cos (30-\phi ) \\ For \; \phi =30^{\circ}, (or \;\pi/6) \\ W_1 &=V_LI_L \cos 60^{\circ} =\frac{V_LI_L}{2} \\ W_2 &=V_LI_L \cos 0^{\circ} =V_LI_L \\ \text {Therefore}\;\;W_2&=2W_1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 In an oscilloscope screen, linear sweep is applied at the
solution: A CRO uses a horizontal input voltage which is an internally generated ramp voltage (i.e. linear sweep voltage) called "Time base of CRO". An oscilloscope is used to disply waveform which varies as a function of time. To reproduce the waveform accurately, the beam must have a constant horizontal velocity i.e. the deflecting voltage must increase linearly with time. This voltage is called a ramp voltage. Thus , a sawtooth waveform also called linear sweep voltage is applied to the horizontal deflection system ( or horizontal axis) which provides a time base to CRO.

question: Question 21 A cascade of three identical modulo-5 counters has an overall modulus of
solution: Overall modulus =5 x 5 x 5=125

question: Question 22 In the Wien Bridge oscillator circuit shown in figure, the bridge is balanced when
solution: [latex]\frac{R_3}{R_4}=\frac{R_1}{R_2}+\frac{C_2}{C_1} [/latex] [latex]\omega =\frac{1}{\sqrt{R_1R_2C_1C_2}}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 The magnitude of the mid-band voltage gain of the circuit shown in figure is
(assuming [latex]h_{fe}[/latex] of the transistor to be 100)
solution: AC model, [latex]\; \; \; \; Z_{i}=10\, k\Omega[/latex] Mid band voltage gain [latex]\; \; \; \; A_{v}=\frac{A_{I}R_{L}}{Z_{i}}[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; A_{v}=\frac{-h_{fe}R_{L}}{Z_{i}} =\frac{-100\times 10\, k\Omega }{10\, k\Omega }=-100[/latex] [latex]\; \; \; \; \left | A_{v} \right |=100[/latex]

question:
Question 24 The figure shows the circuit of a rectifier fed from a 230 V (rms), 50-Hz sinusoidal
voltage source. If we want to replace the current source with a resistor so that the
rms value of the current supplied by the voltage source remains unchanged, the
value of the resistance (in ohms) is _____.
(Assume diodes to be ideal.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{0,rms} &=\frac{V_s}{R}\\ R&=\frac{230}{10}=23\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 25 Figure shows four electronic switches (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv). Which of the switches
can block voltages of either polarity (applied between terminals 'a' and 'b') when
the active device is in the OFF state ?
solution: As given that the active device is in OFF state it means the device can block the voltage when 'a' is positive with respect to 'b' and when 'b' is positive with respect to 'a' then the diode is reverse baised and voltage is blocked. When 'a' is positive with respect to 'b', as given the device is OFF so it will block the voltage. When 'b' is positive with respect to 'a' it will block the voltage. Where as the other two devices will conduct when 'b' is positive with respect to 'a'.

question:
Question 26 Let g : [latex][0,\infty )\rightarrow [0,\infty )[/latex] be a function defined by g(x)=x-[x], where [x] represents the integer part of x . (That is, it is the largest integer which is less than or equal
to x ). The value of the constant term in the Fourier series expansion of g(x) is____.
solution: Given function [latex]g(t)=x-[x][/latex] where, [latex][x][/latex] is a integer part of x Then function [latex]g(x)[/latex] will be The value of the constant term (or) dc term in the Fourier series expansion of [latex]g(x)[/latex] is [latex]\begin{aligned} a_0=\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T}f(x)dx&=\frac{\text{Area in one period}}{\text{one period}}\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times 1=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 27 A fair coin is tossed n times. The probability that the difference between the
number of heads and tails is (n-3) is
solution: [latex](x+y)^n=\sum_{r=0}^{n} {}^nC_r x^{n-r}y^n[/latex] when, n= probability of occurrence of head y= probability of occurrence of tail Let number of head is P. Number of tail is q P+q=n Total number of tails Given:  |P-q|=n-3 |P-(n-P)|=n-3 n=n-3 which is not posssible. Here required probability is zero.

question: Question 28 The line integral of function F=yzi, in the counterclockwise direction, along the circle [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}=1[/latex] at z=1 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{F} &=yz\hat{i} \\ \bigtriangledown \times \bar{F} &=\begin{vmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k}\\ \frac{\partial }{\partial x} & \frac{\partial }{\partial y} &\frac{\partial }{\partial z} \\ yz& 0 & 0 \end{vmatrix} \\ &= \hat{i}(0)-\hat{j}(0-y)+\hat{k}(0-z)\\ &=0\hat{i}+y\hat{j}-z\hat{k} \end{aligned}[/latex] By strokes theoram, [latex]\begin{aligned} \int _C\bar{F}\cdot d\bar{r}&=\int _S (\bigtriangledown \times \bar{F})\cdot \hat{n}ds\\ &=\int _S (y\hat{j}-z\hat{k})\cdot \hat{k}ds\\ &=\int _S -z \; ds \;\;\;\text{ Since }\; z=1\\ &=\int _S -1 \; ds=(-1)S=(-1)\pi =-\pi \end{aligned}[/latex] where S is surface area of [latex]x^2+y^2=1[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;S=\pi(1)^2=\pi[/latex]

question: Question 29 An incandescent lamp is marked 40 W, 240 V. If resistance at room temperature (26[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C) is 120 [latex]\Omega[/latex], and temperature coefficient of resistance is [latex]4.5\times 10^{-3}/^{\circ}[/latex]C, then its 'ON' state filament temperature in [latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is approximately_____.
solution: Let the resistance of incandescent lamp [latex]=R_T=\frac{V^2}{P}=\frac{(240)^2}{40}=1440\Omega[/latex] Given,  [latex]  R_0=120\Omega ,[/latex] [latex]\alpha =4.5 \times 10^{-3}/^{\circ}C [/latex] Let, [latex]R_T[/latex] be the resistance of the filament in ON state at temperature T. Then, [latex] R_T=R_0[1+\alpha \Delta T] [/latex] [latex][1+\alpha \Delta T]=\frac{R_T}{R_0}=\frac{1440}{120}=12[/latex] [latex] \alpha \Delta T=11 [/latex] [latex]\Delta T=2444.44^{\circ}C[/latex] [latex] T=2444.44^{\circ}C+26^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]T=2470.44^{\circ}C [/latex] Therefore, ON state temperature of filament [latex]= 2470.44^{\circ}C[/latex]

question:
Question 30 In the figure, the value of resistor R is (25 + I/2) ohms, where I is the current in
amperes. The current I is _____.
solution: Given, [latex]R=\left ( 25+\frac{I}{2} \right )\Omega [/latex] [latex]I=(2R-50) [/latex] Applying KVL in given loop, we have [latex] 300=IR[/latex] [latex] 300=(2R-50)\times R [/latex] we get, [latex]R=30\Omega \; or \; -5\Omega[/latex] Since, resistance can't be negative. therefore, [latex]R=30\Omega [/latex] Hence,  [latex] I=(2R-50) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=(2 \times 30-50)=10A [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; Current, I=10A[/latex]

question: Question 31 In an unbalanced three phase system, phase current [latex]I_a = 1\angle -90^{\circ}[/latex] pu, negative sequence current [latex]I_{b2}=4 \angle( -150^{\circ})[/latex], zero sequence current [latex]I_{c0}=3 \angle -90^{\circ}[/latex] pu. The magnitude of phase current [latex]I_{b}[/latex]  in pu is
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a&= 1\angle (-90^{\circ})pu\\ I_b&= 4\angle (-150^{\circ})pu\\ I_c&= 3\angle (90^{\circ})pu \end{aligned}[/latex] As zero sequence current in all the three phases of unbalanced [latex]3-\phi[/latex] system are equal, therefore, [latex]I_{a_0}=I_{b_0}=I_{c_0}=3\angle 90^{\circ}pu[/latex] Also,  [latex]I_{b_2}=4\angle -150^{\circ}[/latex] =Negative phase sequence current of phase b. Therefore, referring to the negative phase sequence phasor, [latex]I_{b_2}=4\angle (-150^{\circ}-120^{\circ})=4\angle-270^{\circ}pu[/latex] We know that, phase current vectors in matrix form are given by [latex] \begin{aligned}
\begin{bmatrix}
I_a\\ 
I_b\\ 
I_c
\end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix}
1 &1  &1 \\ 
 1& a^2 &a \\ 
1 & a &a^2 
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
I_{a_0}\\ 
I_{a_1}\\ 
I_{a_2}
\end{bmatrix} \\ 
\text{Here, } I_a&=I_{a_0}+I_{a_1}+I_{a_2} \\ 
\text{Given, } I_a&=1\angle -90^{\circ} \\ 
 I_{a_0}&=3\angle 90^{\circ} \\ 
 I_{a_2}&=4\angle -270^{\circ} \\ 
 \text{Therefore,}& \\ 
 I_{a_1}&=I_a-(I_{a_0}+I_{a_2}) \\ 
 &=(1\angle -90^{\circ})-(3\angle 90^{\circ}+4\angle 270^{\circ}) \\ 
 I_{a_1}&=8\angle -90^{\circ}pu \\ 
 \text{Therefore,}& \\
 I_b&=I_{a_0}+a^2I_{a_1}+aI_{a_2}\\
&=(3\angle 90^{\circ})+(1\angle 120^{\circ})^2 (8\angle -90^{\circ}) \\
&+(1\angle 120^{\circ})(4\angle -270^{\circ})\\
&=3\angle 90^{\circ}+8\angle 150^{\circ}+4\angle -150^{\circ}\\
I_b&=11.53\angle 154.3^{\circ}pu\\
&\text{Magnitude of phase current,}\\
I_b&=11.53\;pu
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 32 The following four vector fields are given in Cartesian co-ordinate system. The
vector field which does not satisfy the property of magnetic flux density is
solution: The property of a solid magnetic field is [latex]\bigtriangledown \cdot B=0[/latex] (i.e. solenoidal property) when, [latex]\begin{aligned} B&=x^2\hat{a_x}+y^2\hat{a_y}+z^2\hat{a_z} \\ \bigtriangledown \cdot B&=2x+2y+2z\neq 0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 The function shown in the figure can be represented as
solution: The given function can be realized as follow: Combining the function (i0, (ii), (iii) and (iv), we get the given function [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Therefore, } f(t)&=u(t)-u(t-T)+\frac{(t-T)}{T}\\ &-u(t-T)-\frac{(t-2T)}{T}u(t-2T)u(t)\\&-u(t-T)+ \frac{1}{T}r(t-T)-\frac{1}{T}r(t-2T)\\ &OR \\ &u(t)-u(t-T)+\frac{1}{T}(t-T)u(t-T)\\&-\frac{1}{T}(t-2T)u(t-2T) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 Let [latex]X(z)=\frac{1}{1-z^{-3}}[/latex]  be the Z -transform of a causal signal x [n]. Then, the values of x[2] and x[3] are
solution: [latex]X(z)=\frac{1}{1-z^{-3}}[/latex] From z-transform defination, [latex]\begin{aligned} X(z)&=\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty }x[n]z^{-n} \\ &=x(0)+x(1)z^{-1}+x(2)z^{-2}+... \\ X(z)&=\frac{1}{1-z^{-3}} \\ &=1+0\cdot z^{-1}+0\cdot z^{-2}+... \end{aligned}[/latex] By comparision x(2)=0 and x(3)=1.

question: Question 35 Let f(t) be a continuous time signal and let F([latex]\omega[/latex]) be its Fourier Transform defined by [latex]F(\omega)=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f(t)e^{-j \omega t}dt[/latex] Define g(t) by [latex]g(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{-jut}du[/latex] What is the relationship between f(t) and g(t) ?
solution: Given that, [latex]\begin{aligned} f(t)&\rightleftharpoons F(\omega )\\ g(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{-jut}du\\ \text{Now, }f(t)&=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(\omega)e^{j \omega t}d\omega \\ \Rightarrow \; 2 \pi f(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(\omega)e^{j \omega t}d\omega \\ \omega &\rightarrow u,\\ 2 \pi f(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{j u t}du \\ t &\rightarrow -t,\\ 2 \pi f(-t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{-j u t}du \\ &=g(t)\\ \Rightarrow \; g(t)&=2 \pi f(-t)\\ &= 2\pi f(t) \end{aligned}[/latex] [If [latex]f(t)[/latex] is even then [latex]f(t)=f(-t)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; g(t) \propto f(t) \text{ if }f(t) \text{ is even.}[/latex]

options.A: g(t) would always be proportional to f (t)
options.B: g(t) would be proportional to f(t) if f(t) is an even function
options.C: g(t) would be proportional to f(t) only if f(t) is a sinusoidal function
options.D: g(t) would never be proportional to f(t)

question: Question 36 The core loss of a single phase, 230/115 V, 50 Hz power transformer is measured from 230 V side by feeding the primary (230 V side) from a variable voltage variable frequency source while keeping the secondary open circuited. The core loss is measured to be 1050 W for 230 V, 50 Hz input. The core loss is again measured to be 500 W for 138 V, 30 Hz input. The hysteresis and eddy current losses of the transformer for 230 V, 50 Hz input are respectively,
solution: Given, at 230V, 50 Hz, core loss =1050 W and at 138 V, 30 Hz, core loss =500 W Let, [latex]V_1=230 V, \;f_1=50Hz[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Eddy current loss} &=P_{e1} \\ \text{Hysteresis loss}&=P_{h1} \\ V_2=138V &, f_230Hz \\ \text{Eddy current loss} &=P_{e2} \\ \text{Hysteresis loss}&=P_{h2} \\ \text{we know that, } & \\ \text{Eddy current loss,}\;& P_e \propto B_m^2f^2 \\ \text{and hysteresis loss,}&P_h \propto B_m^xf\propto B_m^1.6 f \\ &(\text{Typical value of x=1.6}) \end{aligned}[/latex] The transformer induced emf equation is: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1 &=\sqrt{2} \pi \phi _m N \\ V_1&= \sqrt{2} \pi f B_m A N\\ \text{where,}\;\; \frac{V}{t} &=\text{constant} \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e. flux = constant ( to avoid over fluxing) [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Eddy current loss,} &P_e \propto V^2 \\ \text{and hysteresis loss,}&P_h \propto\frac{V^{1.6}}{f^{0.6}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_{e2}}{P_{e1}} &=\left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^2=\left ( \frac{138}{230} \right )^2=0.36 \\ \text{or,} \;\; P_{e2} &= 0.36P_{e1}\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Also,} \;\;\frac{P_{h2}}{P_{e1}} &=\left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^{1.6} \times \left ( \frac{f_1}{f_2} \right )^{0.6}\\ &=\left ( \frac{138}{230} \right )^{1.6} \times \left ( \frac{50}{30} \right )^{0.6} \\ &= (0.6)^{1.6} \times \frac{1}{(0.6)^{0.6}}=0.6\\ \therefore \;\; P_{h2} &=0.6P_{h1} \;\;...(ii) \end{aligned} [/latex] Given at 230V, 50Hz [latex]\text{Core loss}=P_{e1}+P_{h1}=1050W\;\;...(iii) [/latex] At 138V, 30Hz, [latex]\text{Core loss}=P_{e2}+P_{h2}=500W [/latex] or,   [latex]0.36P_{e1}+0.6P_{h1}=500W\;\;...(iv)[/latex] solving equation (iii) and (iv), we get [latex]P_{h1}=508W [/latex] and [latex] P_{e1}=542W[/latex] Therefore, hysteresis and eddy current losses at 230V, 50Hz are 508W and 542W respectively.

question: Question 37 A 15 kW, 230 V dc shunt motor has armature circuit resistance of 0.4 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and field circuit resistance of 230 [latex]\Omega[/latex] . At no load and rated voltage, the motor runs at 1400 rpm and the line current drawn by the motor is 5 A. At full load, the motor draws a line current of 70 A. Neglect armature reaction. The full load speed of the motor in rpm is_____.
solution: Given, [latex]R_a=0.4\Omega , [/latex] [latex]R_f=230\Omega , [/latex]  [latex]V=230 \;\text{volt} [/latex] At no load, speed, [latex]N_0=1400 \;\text{rpm}, [/latex]  [latex]I_{L_0}=5A [/latex] Field current,  [latex]I_f=\frac{V}{R_f}=\frac{230}{230}=1A[/latex] No load armature current, [latex]I_{a_0}=5-1=4A[/latex] Induced emf at no-load, [latex]E_{a_0}=V-I_{a_0}R_a[/latex] [latex]\;\; \;\;=230-4 \times 0.4=228.4 V [/latex] Also, at full load, [latex]I_{L_{fl}}=70A [/latex] [latex]I_{a_{fl}}=I_{L_{fl}}-I_f=70-1=69A [/latex] Induced emf at full load, [latex]E_{a_{fl}}=V-I_{a{fl}}R_a [/latex] [latex]E_{a_{fl}}=230 -69 \times 0.4=202.4V [/latex] we know that, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a&\propto \phi \omega _m \alpha \propto N \\ E_a &\propto N \\ (\text{as flux} \; \phi \; &\text{is constant in shunt motor}) \\ \therefore \; \frac{E_{a_{fl}}}{E_{a_{0}}} &=\frac{N_{fl}}{N_0} \\ N_{fl}&= \frac{E_{a_{fl}}}{E_{a_{0}}} \times N_0 \\ &=\left ( \frac{202.4}{228.4} \right ) \times 1400 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, full-load speed of motor = 1240.63 rpm

question: Question 38 A 3 phase, 50 Hz, six pole induction motor has a rotor resistance of 0.1[latex]\Omega[/latex] and reactance of 0.92[latex]\Omega[/latex] . Neglect the voltage drop in stator and assume that the rotor resistance is constant. Given that the full load slip is 3%, the ratio of maximum torque to full load torque is
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} R'_2 &=0.1\Omega \\ X'_2&= 0.92\Omega \\ S_{fl}&=3\%=0.03 \end{aligned}[/latex] Slip at maximum torque, [latex] S_m=\frac{R'_2}{X'_2}=\frac{0.1}{0.92}=0.1087 [/latex] We know that, [latex]\begin{aligned}\frac{T_{fl}}{T_{em}}&=\frac{2}{\left ( \frac{S_m}{S_{fl}}+\frac{S_{fl}}{S_m} \right )}\\ \therefore \;\; \frac{T_{fl}}{T_{em}}&=\frac{2}{\left ( \frac{0.1087}{0.03}+\frac{0.03}{0.1087} \right )}\\ &=\frac{2}{3.623+0.275}=\frac{2}{3.898}\\ \frac{T_{em}}{T_{fl}}&= 1.949 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, ratio of maximum torque to full-load torque [latex]=\frac{T_{em}}{T_{fl}}= 1.949[/latex]

question: Question 39 A three phase synchronous generator is to be connected to the infinite bus. The lamps are connected as shown in the figure for the synchronization. The phase sequence of bus voltage is R-Y-B and that of incoming generator voltage is R' - Y' - B'. It was found that the lamps are becoming dark in the sequence [latex]L_a-L_b-L_c[/latex]. It means that the phase sequence of incoming generator is
solution: As, [latex]\begin{aligned} L_a \; \text{is connected between R-R'} & \\ L_b \; \text{is connected between Y-Y'} & \\ L_c \; \text{is connected between B-B'} & \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] therefore, the given method of synchronization is called "synchronization by dark lmap method". In this method of synchronization, correct phase sequence of the incoming generator is obtain when all the three lamps become dark together and bright together. Since lamps are becoming dark in the sequence [latex]L_a-L_b-L_c[/latex] therefore, the phase sequence of incoming generator is opposite to the infinite bus.

options.A: opposite to infinite bus and its frequency is more than infinite bus
options.B: opposite to infinite bus but its frequency is less than infinite bus
options.C: same as infinite bus and its frequency is more than infinite bus
options.D: same as infinite bus and its frequency is less than infinite bus

question: Question 40 A distribution feeder of 1 km length having resistance, but negligible reactance, is fed from both the ends by 400 V, 50 Hz balanced sources. Both voltage sources [latex]S_1 \; and \; S_2[/latex] are in phase. The feeder supplies concentrated loads of unity power factor as shown in the figure. The contributions of [latex]S_1 \; and \; S_2[/latex] in 100 A current supplied at location P respectively, are
solution:
Let the resistance of whole length of feeder be [latex]R\;\Omega[/latex], length of feeder =1000m. [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Resistance per unit length [latex]=\frac{R}{1000}\Omega /meter[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Resistance of 400 m length [latex]=\frac{R}{1000} \times 400 =\frac{2R}{5} \Omega [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Resistance of 200 m length [latex] =\frac{R}{5} \Omega [/latex] Let the current supplied by the sources be [latex]I_1 \text{ and } I_2[/latex]. Applying KVL from source [latex]S_1 \text{ and } S_2[/latex], we have: [latex]\begin{aligned}
400 &= \frac{2R}{5}I_1+\frac{R}{5}(I_1-200)\\ & -\frac{R}{5}(I_2-200)-\frac{R}{5}I_2+400\\ 
 0&= \frac{2}{5}I_1 +\frac{I_1-200}{5}+\frac{200-I_2}{5}-\frac{I_2}{5}\\ 
 0&=2I_1+I_1-200+200-I_2-I_2 \\ 
 0&=3I_1-2I_2\\
I_1&=\frac{2}{3}I_2\;\;\;...(i)\\
\text{also, }& I_1 +I_2-400=100\\
\text{or, }&I_1+I_2=500 \;\;\;...(ii)\\
&\text{Solvinf eq. (i) and (ii), we have}\\
I_1&=200A \text{ and }I_2=300A\\
&\text{Contribution of }S_1 \text{in 100 A at location}\\
P&=I_1-200=0A \\
&\text{Contribution of }S_2 \text{in 100 A at location}\\
P&=I_2-200=300-200=100A
\end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, [latex]S_2[/latex] alone supplies the total load at location P.

question: Question 41 A two bus power system shown in the figure supplies load of 1.0+j0.5 p.u. The values of [latex]V_1[/latex] in p.u. and [latex]\delta _2[/latex] respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_2+jQ_2&=(1.0+j0.5)p.u.\\ P_2&=1=\frac{|V_1||V_2|}{|X|} \sin (\delta _1-\delta _2)\\ 1&=\frac{V_1}{0.1}\sin (-\delta _2)\\ -\frac{0.1}{\sin (-\delta _2)}&=V_1\;\;...(i)\\ Q_2&=0.5=\frac{|V_2|}{|X|}(|V_1| \cos \delta _2 -|V_2|)\\ 0.5&=\frac{1}{0.1}(V_1 \cos \delta _2-1)\\ \frac{1.05}{\cos \delta _2}&=V_1\;\;...(ii)\\ &\text{From equation (i) and (ii),}\\ \tan \delta _2&=\frac{-0.1}{1.05}\\ \delta _2&=-5.44^{\circ}\\ \text{substituting } & \delta _2 \text{ value in equation (ii) gives,}\\ V_1&=1.05\;p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 42 The fuel cost functions of two power plants are Plant [latex]P_1:C_1\equiv 0.05Pg^2_1+APg_1+B[/latex] Plant [latex]P_2:C_2\equiv 0.10Pg^2_2+3APg_2+2B[/latex] where, [latex]Pg_1 \; and \; Pg_2[/latex] are the generated powers of two plants, and A and B are the
constants. If the two plants optimally share 1000 MW load at incremental fuel
cost of 100 Rs/MWh, the ratio of load shared by plants [latex]P_1 \; and \; P_2[/latex] is
solution: Given, [latex]P_{g1}+P_{g2}=1000 \;\;...(i)[/latex] Also, incremental cost of production of [latex]g_1=\frac{dC_1}{dP_{g1}}=0.1P_{g1}+A \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] and incremental cost of production of [latex]g_2=\frac{dC_2}{dP_{g2}}=0.2P_{g2}+3A\;\;\;...(iii)[/latex] For optimum load sharing [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dC_1}{dP_{g1}}&=\frac{dC_2}{dP_{g2}} \\ 0.1P_{g1}+A&=0.2P_{g2}+3A \\ 0.1P_{g1}-0.2P_{g2}&=2A \\ P_{g1}-2P_{g2}&=20A \;\;\;...(iv) \\ \text{Given, } \frac{dC_1}{dP_{g1}}&=\frac{dC_2}{dP_{g2}}=100\; Rs/MWh \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting this value in equation (ii), we have [latex]\begin{aligned} 100&=0.1P_{g1}+A\\ A&=(100-0.1P_{g1})\;\;...(v) \end{aligned}[/latex] Using equation (iv) and (v), we have: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{g1}-2P_{g2}&=20(100-0.1P_{g1})\\ 3P_{g1}-2P_{g2}&=20004\;\;...(vi) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{g1}&=800MW \text{ and } P_{g2}=200MW\\ \therefore \;P_{g1}:P_{g2}&=800:200=4:1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 The over current relays for the line protection and loads connected at the buses
are shown in the figure. The relays are IDMT in nature having the characteristic [latex]t_{op}=\frac{0.14\times Time \;  Multipller \; Setting}{(Plug \; Setting \; Multiplier)^{0.02}-1}[/latex] The maximum and minimum fault currents at bus B are 2000 A and 500 A
respectively. Assuming the time multiplier setting and plug setting for relay [latex]R_B[/latex]
to be 0.1 and 5 A respectively, the operating time of [latex]R_B[/latex] (in seconds) is_____.
solution: Minimum and maximum fault currents are [latex]I_{fmin}=500A, I_{fmax}=2000A[/latex] For relay [latex]R_B,\;TMS=0.1[/latex], plug setting =5A [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{PSM}&=\frac{I_f}{I_{pk} \times \text{C.T. ratio}} \\ \text{C.T. ratio} &=\frac{\text{Full load current}}{I_{pk}} \\ &= \frac{100}{5}\\ \text{At realy, }&R_B\\ \text{with }I_{fmin}\Rightarrow & \text{PSM}_1=\frac{500}{\frac{100}{5}\times 5}=5\\ \text{with }I_{fmax}\Rightarrow & \text{PSM}_2=\frac{2000}{\frac{100}{5}\times 5}=20 \end{aligned}[/latex] Operating time with TMS=0.1, and from IDMT characterisrics [latex]t_{op_2}=\frac{0.14 \times 0.1}{(20)^{0.02}-1}=0.226sec[/latex]

question:
Question 44 For the given system, it is desired that the system be stable. The minimum value
of [latex]\alpha[/latex] for this condition is ______.
solution: Given, [latex]G(s)=\frac{(s+\alpha )}{s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+(\alpha -1)s+(1-\alpha )} [/latex] and  [latex] H(s)=1[/latex] Characteristic equation of given control system is given by [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] or, [latex] 1+\left [ \frac{s+\alpha }{s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+(\alpha -1)s+(1-\alpha )} \right ]=0[/latex] or, [latex] s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+(\alpha -1)s+(1-\alpha )+s+\alpha =0 [/latex] or,  [latex] s^3+(1+\alpha )s^2+\alpha s+1=0[/latex] Routh's array is For the given system to be stable, there should not be any sign change in the first column of Routh's array. Therefore, [latex]1+\alpha \gt 0 \;or, \; \alpha \gt -1\;\; ...(i)[/latex] Also,  [latex] \frac{\alpha ^2 +\alpha -1}{1+\alpha } \gt 0 [/latex] or,  [latex]   \alpha ^2 +\alpha -1 \gt 0 [/latex] or,  [latex] (\alpha +1.618)(\alpha -0.618) \gt 0 [/latex] or,   [latex] \alpha \lt -1.618[/latex] or,  [latex] \alpha \gt 0.618[/latex] As  [latex] \alpha \gt -1[/latex] (using equation (i)) therefore, [latex]\alpha \gt 0.618 \;\;...(ii) [/latex] Combining condition (i) and (ii), [latex] -1 \lt \alpha \lt 0.618 [/latex] Thus, for the system to be stable minimum value of  [latex]\alpha =0.618.[/latex]

question: Question 45 The Bode magnitude plot of the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1+0.5s)(1+as)}{s(1+\frac{s}{8})(1+bs)(1+\frac{s}{36})}[/latex] is shown below: Note that -6 dB/octave =- 20 dB/decade. The value of [latex]\frac{a}{bK}[/latex] is _____.
solution:
Given, [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1+0.5s)(1+as)}{s(1+\frac{s}{8})(1+bs)(1+\frac{s}{36})}[/latex] (1+as) is addition of zero to the transfer function whose contribution in slope=+20 dB/decade or -6 dB/octave. (1+bs) is addition of pole to the transfer function whose contribution in slope=-20 dB/decade or -6 dB/octave. Observing the change in the slope at different corner frequencies, we conclude that, [latex]
a=\frac{1}{4}[/latex] rad/s and [latex]b=\frac{1}{24}[/latex] rad/s From[latex] \omega =0.01[/latex] rad/s to [latex]\omega =8[/latex] rad/s, slope=-20dB/decade Let the vertical length in dB by y [latex]\therefore \;\; -20=\left ( \frac{0-y}{log8-log0.01} \right )[/latex] [latex] \;\;\;\; -20=\frac{y}{log 8+2}[/latex] [latex]
\;\;\;\; y=58 dB[/latex] Applying, [latex]y-mx+C[/latex] at [latex]\omega =0.01[/latex] rad/s, We have, [latex]58=-20log 0.01 +C[/latex] [latex]C=58-40=18[/latex] Now, [latex]C=20logK[/latex] [latex]
LogK=\frac{18}{20}=0.9[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \;\; K= log^{-1}(0.9)=(10)^{0.9}=7.94[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \;\; \frac{a}{bK}=\frac{\left ( \frac{1}{4} \right )}{\left ( \frac{1}{24} \right )\times 7.94}=\frac{24}{4 \times 7.94}=0.755[/latex]

question:
Question 46 A system matrix is given as follows [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & -1\\ -6& -11&6 \\ -6 & -11 & 5 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The absolute value of the ratio of the maximum eigenvalue to the minimum
eigenvalue is _______.
solution: Characteristic equation [latex]|A-\lambda I|=0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \begin{vmatrix} -\lambda & 1 & -1\\ -6 & -11-\lambda & 6\\ -6&-11 & 5-\lambda \end{vmatrix} = 0\\ \Rightarrow \; -\lambda [-55+11\lambda -5\lambda +\lambda ^2+66] \\ -1[-30+6\lambda +36]-1[66-66-6\lambda ]=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; -\lambda (\lambda ^2+6\lambda +11)-1(6\lambda +6)+6\lambda =0 \\ \Rightarrow \;-\lambda ^3-6\lambda ^2-11\lambda -6=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\lambda ^3+6\lambda ^2+11\lambda +6=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; (\lambda +1)(\lambda +2)(\lambda +3)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\lambda =-1,-2,-3 \end{aligned}[/latex] The absolute values of [latex]\lambda[/latex] are [latex]|\lambda |=1,2,3[/latex] Ratio of maximum and minimum eigen value is [latex]=3:1=\frac{3}{1}=3[/latex]

question:
Question 47 The reading of the voltmeter (rms) in volts, for the circuit shown in the figure is
_________
solution: Given bridge is shown in figure From the given bridge circuit, we see that product of opposite arm impedance are equal [latex]\begin{aligned} i.e. \;\;& (-j) \times (-j)=(j)(j)\\ or\;\;\; & -1= -1 \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, the bridge is balanced, i.e. no current flows through the voltage source V. Now, [latex]\begin{aligned} v_i(t)&= 100 \sin \omega t\\ &= \frac{100}{\sqrt{2}} \text{Volt(rms value)}\\ \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Net current supplied by the source is [latex]I=\frac{100\sqrt{2}}{(0.5+Z_{eq})}A [/latex] [latex]Z_{eq}=0 [/latex](i.e. net impedance of whole bridge=0) [latex]\therefore \;\; I=\frac{100\sqrt{2}}{0.5}=141.42A [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;\frac{I_2}{2}=70.71A [/latex] Current flow through each parallel path of the bridge circuit, therefore [latex]V=V_a-V_b [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\left ( \frac{I}{2} \times -j \right )-\left ( \frac{I}{2} \times j \right ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=-jI=-j141.42[/latex] volt (rms value) [latex]\therefore[/latex] Reading of the voltmeter in volt (rms) [latex]=V=V_{ab}=141.42[/latex]

question:
Question 48 The dc current flowing in a circuit is measured by two ammeters, one PMMC
and another electrodynamometer type, connected in series. The PMMC meter
contains 100 turns in the coil, the flux density in the air gap is 0.2Wb/[latex]m^2[/latex], and
the area of the coil is 80 [latex]mm^2[/latex]. The electrodynamometer ammeter has a change in
mutual inductance with respect to deflection of 0.5 mH/deg. The spring constants
of both the meters are equal. The value of current, at which the deflections of the
two meters are same, is ______
solution: For a PMMC ammeter, at equilibrim, we have : controlling torque ([latex]T_c[/latex])=Deflecting torque([latex]T_d[/latex]) [latex]\begin{aligned} K\theta _1 &=GI \; \text{or}\; \theta _1=\frac{GI}{K}\\ where, \;\; G &= nBA\\ \therefore \; \theta _1 &= \frac{nBAI}{K} \end{aligned}[/latex] For an electrodynometer ammeter, at equilibrium, Controlling torque=Deflecting torque [latex]\begin{aligned} i.e. \;\; T_c &=T_d \; \text{or}\; K \theta _2=I^2 \frac{dM}{d\theta }\\ or, \;\; \theta _2 &= \frac{I^2}{K}\cdot \frac{dM}{d\theta }\;\;...(ii)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] For the deflection in the two meter to be same, [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta _1 &=\theta _2\\ or, \;\; \frac{nBAI}{K} &= \frac{I^2}{K}\cdot \frac{dM}{d\theta }\\ or, \;\; nBA&=I\frac{dM}{d\theta }\\ or, \;\; I &=\frac{nBA}{\left ( \frac{dM}{d\theta } \right )} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} Given, \;\; n&= \text{number of turns}=100\\ B&= 0.2 Wb/m^2\\ A&=80mm^2=80 \times 10^{-6}m^2\\ \text{and}\;\; \frac{dM}{d\theta }&=0.5 mH/rad\\ &=0.5 \times 10^{-3}H/rad \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting the values in I, we get [latex]\begin{aligned} I &=\left ( \frac{100 \times 0.2 \times 80 \times 10^{-6}}{0.5 \times 10^{-3}} \right ) A\\ &= \frac{1.6}{0.5}=3.2A \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Required value of current, [latex]I=3.2Amp.[/latex]

question: Question 49 Given that the op-amps in the figure are ideal, the output voltage [latex]V_o[/latex] is
solution: Op-amp '3' circuit is a differential amplifier so, [latex]V_o=V_{01}-V_{02}...(i)[/latex] Now, apply KCL at node '2' [latex]\frac{V_2-V_1}{2R}+\frac{V_2-V_{02}}{R}=0...(ii)[/latex] and apply KCL at node '1' [latex]\frac{V_1-V_2}{2R}+\frac{V_1-V_{01}}{R}=0...(iii)[/latex] From equation (i), (ii) and (iii), we get [latex]V_0=2(V_1-V_2)[/latex]

question:
Question 50 Which of the following logic circuits is a realization of the function F whose
Karnaugh map is shown in figure
solution: [latex]F=\bar{A}\bar{C}+BC[/latex]

question:
Question 51 In the figure shown, assume the op-amp to be ideal. Which of the alternatives
gives the correct Bode plote for the transfer function [latex]\frac{V_o(\omega)}{V_{i}(\omega)}[/latex]
?
solution: This filter is considered as low-pass filter (LPF). The transfer function for LPF [latex]\frac{V_o}{V_i}=\frac{\frac{1}{sC}}{R+\frac{1}{sC}}=\frac{1}{1+sCR} [/latex] [latex]\;\; =\frac{1}{1+j\omega (10)^3(10^{-6})}=\frac{1}{1+j\omega (10^{-3})} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1000}{1000+j\omega }=\frac{1}{1+\frac{s}{1000}} [/latex] [latex]\omega _c[/latex] (corner frequency)= [latex]10^3[/latex] rad/sec. tha gain at low frequencies, [latex]A_V=\frac{1}{1+sCR}=\frac{1}{1}=1[/latex]

question:
Question 52 An output device is interfaced with 8-bit microprocessor 8085A. The interfacing
circuit is shown in figure The interfacing circuit makes use of 3 Line to 8 Line decoder having 3 enables lines [latex]E_1,\bar{E_2},\bar{E_3}[/latex]. The address of the device is
solution: For the given decoder [latex]E-=A_{12}\bar{A_{11}}=1 (enable) [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; A_{12} [/latex] should be HIGH and  [latex]A_{11} [/latex] should be LOW. Also,  [latex]E_2=E_3=0(disable) [/latex] The decoder output depends on  [latex]I_2=A_{15}, I_1=A_{14} [/latex] and  [latex]I_0=A_{13}  [/latex]which should be 010 respectively to enable the output port. The address of the device is 5000H-57FFH,

question:
Question 53 The figure shows the circuit diagram of a rectifier. The load consists of a resistance
10 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and an inductance 0.05 H connected in series. Assuming ideal thyristor and
ideal diode, the thyristor firing angle (in degree) needed to obtain an average load
voltage of 70 V is ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&=\frac{V_m}{2 \pi}(1+ \cos \alpha )\\ \frac{70 \times 2 \pi}{325}&= \cos \alpha \\ \alpha &=\cos ^{-1}\left ( \frac{70 \times 2 \pi}{325}-1 \right )\\ \alpha &=69^{\circ}31' \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 Figure (i) shows the circuit diagram of a chopper. The switch S in the circuit in
figure (i) is switched such that the voltage [latex]v_D[/latex] across the diode has the wave shape
as shown in figure (ii). The capacitance C is large so that the voltage across it is
constant. If switch S and the diode are ideal, the peak to peak ripple (in A) in
the inductor current is ______
solution: The circuit shown is a Buck chopper [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&=V_s\frac{T_{ON}}{T}\\ V_0&=100 \times \frac{0.05 \times 10^{-3}}{0.1 \times 10^{-3}}=50V \end{aligned}[/latex] The peak to peak ripple in the inductor current is [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta I&=\frac{V_0T_{OFF}}{L}\\ &=50 \times \frac{0.05 \times 10^{-3}}{1 \times 10^{-3}}\\ \Delta I&=2.5A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 The figure shows one period of the output voltage of an inverter. [latex]\alpha[/latex] should be
chosen such that [latex]60^{\circ} \lt \alpha \lt 90^{\circ}[/latex]. If rms value of the fundamental component is 50V, then [latex]\alpha[/latex]  in degree is _____.
solution: The output voltage [latex]V_0[/latex] can be reprresnted by fourier series as under: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&=\sum_{n=1,3,5,...}^{\infty }a_n \cos n\omega t+b_n \sin n\omega t\\ \text{where, } a_n&=\frac{2}{T}\int_{0}^{T}f(t)\cos n\omega t \;d(\omega t) \\ b_n&=\frac{2}{T}\int_{0}^{T}f(t)\sin n\omega t \;d(\omega t) \\ a_n&=\frac{1}{\pi} [\int_{0}^{\alpha }100 \cos \omega t \;d(\omega t) +\int_{\alpha }^{180^{\circ}-\alpha }(-100) \cos \omega t \;d(\omega t) \\ &+ \int_{180^{\circ}-\alpha}^{180^{\circ} }100 \cos \omega t \;d(\omega t) +\int_{180^{\circ} }^{180^{\circ}+\alpha }(-100) \cos \omega t \;d(\omega t)\\ &+ \int_{180^{\circ}+\alpha}^{360^{\circ} -\alpha }100 \cos \omega t \;d(\omega t) +\int_{360^{\circ}-\alpha }^{360^{\circ} }(-100) \cos \omega t \;d(\omega t)]\\ a_n &=\frac{100}{\pi}[\sin \alpha - \sin (180^{\circ} -\alpha ) + \sin \alpha \\ &+\sin (180^{\circ}) -\sin (180^{\circ} -\alpha )\\ &- \sin (180^{\circ} +\alpha ) + \sin 180^{\circ}\\ &+ \sin (360^{\circ} -\alpha )- \sin (180^{\circ} +\alpha ) \\ &- \sin (360^{\circ} ) + \sin (360^{\circ} -\alpha )]\\ a_n &=0 \\ b_n&=\frac{1}{\pi} [\int_{0}^{\alpha }100 \sin \omega t \;d(\omega t) +\int_{\alpha }^{180^{\circ}-\alpha }(-100) \sin \omega t \;d(\omega t) \\ &+ \int_{180^{\circ}-\alpha}^{180^{\circ} }100 \sin \omega t \;d(\omega t) +\int_{180^{\circ} }^{180^{\circ}+\alpha }(-100) \sin \omega t \;d(\omega t)\\ &+ \int_{180^{\circ}+\alpha}^{360^{\circ} -\alpha }100 \sin \omega t \;d(\omega t) +\int_{360^{\circ}-\alpha }^{360^{\circ} }(-100) \sin \omega t \;d(\omega t)]\\ b_n &=\frac{100}{\pi}[-\cos \alpha +1+ \cos (180^{\circ} -\alpha ) - \cos \alpha \\ &-\cos (180^{\circ}) +\cos (180^{\circ} -\alpha )\\ &+ \cos (180^{\circ} +\alpha ) - \cos 180^{\circ}\\ &- \cos (360^{\circ} -\alpha )+ \cos (180^{\circ} +\alpha ) \\ &+ \cos (360^{\circ} ) - \cos (360^{\circ} -\alpha )]\\ b_n&=\frac{100}{\pi}[4-8 \cos \alpha ] =50\sqrt{2}\\ \cos \alpha &=0.22231=77.15^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]
